Quoth Sanjay Mantoor:
> How  data driven test cases can be done in JUnit without much change in test
> script?

There are JUnit extensions that do data-driven testing -- see the
list on the JUnit website.

Or you could write your own framework for this.  An obvious
approach:

1. Write an abstract class which implements Test and does the
grunt work of getting the test data and making it available to
subclasses in some easy-to-use fashion.

2. Write your data-driven tests by extending this class instead of
TestCase.

3. Write a static utility method which instantiates such classes
once for each available set of test data.

Slap it all together, and voilï¿½!  (Make sure you're wearing safety
goggles.)

> What way Test results can be moved to log file.

Here's there ways:

1. Use Ant.  Its <junit> task logs to a file by default.

2. Run your tests like so:
   $ java junit.textui.TestRunner MyTests 2>&1 >logfile

3. Write your own TestListener that logs as you wish.  (Getting
this to work can be tricky, since the documentation is inadequate
in this area.  It's not obvious, for example, how to attach one's
own TestListener to one of the stock TestRunners.  If you want to
pursue this option and need help, ask.)
